div.head: Introduction
div.p: Density modelling Survey site optimisation Image classification Density modelling problem
In a crop disease survey, each plant is assigned a disease level y i ∈ {d 1 , ..., d D }.
The observed data is of the form D = {x i , y i |i = 1, . . . , N} where x i ∈ R 2 is a spatial location.
We would like to infer P(y * |x * , D).
Can then calculate things like incidence, the proportion of infected plants: P(y * > d 1 |x * ).

We should deal with the observations y i as ordinal categories, d 1 < d 2 < · · · < d D , and not code them as numbers: we do not have a principled way of mapping these categories to the real line, for example.

If possible, we should deal with observations in continuous space, rather than losing information through aggregation. It is more important to assess whether an area is diseased or not, than to accurately guess the specific severity.

We can use GP regression with ordinal observed data to model density in continuous space.
First, define a hidden function of the location f (x i ), and specify a covariance between the function at different positions:
div.formula: K (x i , x j ) = exp − κ 2 x i,1 − x j,1 2 + x i,2 − x j,2 2
div.p: Then relate the observations with this hidden function with a likelihood term: p(y i |f (x i )).
We then integrate out f (x i ) to obtain a distribution across ordinal categories at each location.

div.p: We have an online variation of this problem: surveyors are on a road circuit (represented as a 1D manifold R), and we keep moving in the same direction.
Hence we will often prefer to sample a nearby point before sampling a distant point, even if the latter is expected to be more informative.

Currently, the survey plan is to sample at roughly equal intervals along R. Beyond the smallest number of survey locations (sampling too sparse for adaptive method to be effective), and high number of locations (in which every location is thoroughly sampled) the mean utility ratio L Adaptive L Regular is significantly below 1.

div.head: Density modelling
div.p: Survey site optimisation Image classification Image-based classification of disease One of the constraints on crop disease surveying currently is the scarcity of experts.
When mobile data collection replaces paper-based surveying, camera-phones can be used to collect image data.

If we can use these images to perform a diagnosis of disease automatically, then agricultural extension workers with basic training can carry out the survey. We extract two types of features from these images: hue histograms, and SIFT descriptors.

The automated scheme has equivalent utility when at least 70% extra data is obtained.

div.head: Summary
div.p: We have introduced a density model, survey optimisation method, and image-based disease classification method.
These techniques can bring significant savings in both survey cost and time.
This also increases in the amount of data which can be collected: extension workers can be issued with phones and provide data year round.
We are planning national survey of cassava disease in Uganda this year.
